instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; it should start when charger is connected (no battery present).
Use an USB macOS pendrive with Link LED, to check for USB activity (if is the case).
Check voltage (at least pulse) at all big coils, in the first seconds.

when its off its show 19v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
I mentioned fan spin as you said does it for 1s; so voltages should appear, at least pulse that time.
No need to connect fan, nor other thing; just check voltage in that time you know fan was spinning.
Fan requires 5V to spin, other voltages try to appear at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
Not always (very) low ohm value is short.
Please, try to understand the difference.

CPU coils have very low values normally; however, not bellow 1 ohm.
Compare with similar CPU.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looping???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
Why do you bother with L7030???
It is not directly connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> like in old boards.
If <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable, there is no problem on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area.
The problem is that SMC (inside T2) does NOT properly communicate with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead

[/QUOTE]
i just sew that its loop so....
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 63806, member: 682"]
The problem is that SMC (inside T2) does NOT properly communicate with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
[/QUOTE]
how can i find the bad communication? do i need to replace the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
You cannot replace SMC; it is part of T2 now.

I suppose board still has problems caused by corrosion.
This could be the reason is not listed on the other MacBook for DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
So where can i search? 
What can i do? What can be the reason?
Or i need to give up?
Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
Could be just one corroded resistor, or accumulated crap under some BGA chip.
Is not an easy case; may be waste of time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
Do not check DC voltage on L7030.
It is not directly connected with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; didn't see <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>?
And STOP to check Gate MOSFETs for voltage, is irrelevant.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage fan work but dead
threads.message:
The heat applied to the board changed the behaviour.
Something else reacted at heat.
There should be more things affected by corrosion.
Try heating BGA chips with quality flux and pass to board trough ultrasonic cleaner at the end.
